definition: A removable metal plate that clips onto a detachable headshell to increase the effective mass of the tonearm-cartridge system, improving tracking stability and optimizing resonance characteristics. Typically constructed from brass, steel, or tungsten and weighing between 2 and 6 grams, these accessories became essential tools during the 1970s high-compliance cartridge era when audiophiles needed to match tonearm mass to specific cartridge designs. The clip-on weight attaches to the top or sides of the headshell without requiring permanent modification, allowing users to fine-tune the tonearm's resonant frequency to the ideal 8-12 Hz range. This adjustment prevents mistracking, reduces warp-induced wow, and minimizes feedback in systems with high-output speakers. Japanese manufacturers like Audio-Technica and Technics popularized standardized clip-on designs compatible with their universal headshells, while boutique audio companies offered precision-machined versions in exotic materials. Modern turntable enthusiasts employ these weights when using vintage high-compliance cartridges on contemporary lightweight tonearms, or when attempting to stabilize playback of warped records. The practice remains particularly common in DJ setups where battle-style scratching demands maximum tracking force and headshell rigidity.
etymology: Coined in the early 1970s when detachable headshells became standardized, combining the attachment method (clip-on) with the component location (headshell) and function (weight/mass addition).
